person:biography.personal-details:content: Mert Terzi was born in 1982. He has got his Ph.D. degree from Istanbul University, Mining Engineering Programme in 2017. He started his academic career as a research assistant at Istanbul University Mining Engineering Department in 2012 and still pursing working in the same unit. His field of work includes mineral processing, evaluation of mineral processing tailings, application of digital image processing methods in mineral processing, beneficiation of titanium minerals, feldspar ores and rare earth elements and he has 9 international and 3 national papers and 28 published conference proceedings.

work:title.common:title: Distribution of trace elements in coal and coal fly ash and their recovery with mineral processing practices: A review
Evaluation of digital image processing (DIP) in analysis of magnetic separation fractions from Na-feldspar ore
Solubility of Eskisehir thorium/rare earth ores in sulphuric and nitric acids
HCl leaching behaviour of a bastnasite ore in terms of thorium and rare earth elements
RECOVERY OF TRACE ELEMENTS WITH URANIUM AND THORIUM FROM YATAGAN THERMAL POWER PLANT FLY ASHES BY LEACHING
Research on the Solubility of Radioactive Elements in the Ashes from the Soma in Turkey

work:work-summary.work:journal-title: Mineral Processing and Extractive Metallurgy Review

work:title.common:title: Silver Leaching from Lead-Zinc Process Tailings in Balya Mines

work:work-summary.work:journal-title: Proceeding of 16th International Symposium on Environmental Issues and Waste Management in Energy and Mineral Production (Swemp 2016)

work:title.common:title: Investigation of recovery possibilities of rutile minerals from the feldspar tailings with gravity separation methods
The Dissolution of Vanadium in Silica Sand with Organic and Inorganic Acids

work:work-summary.work:journal-title: Proceedings of the 24th International Mining Congress and Exhibition of Turkey, IMCET 2015

work:title.common:title: BENEFICIATION OF LOW-GRADE FELDSPAR ORE USING CYCLOJET FLOTATION CELL, CONVENTIONAL CELL AND MAGNETIC SEPARATOR
